prompt.stem: A circuit is set up as shown. The resistance of the variable resistor is changed and the corresponding readings on the ammeter and voltmeter are used to produce the graph shown. A student makes the following statements based on this information: I The EMF of the battery is 12 V. II The internal resistance of the battery is 10 Ω. III The short circuit current is 1.2 A. Which of these statements is/are correct?

level1: Use the battery model V = E − Ir and interpret the straight-line V–I graph.
level2: Find the gradient (−r) from two clear points on the graph, then find E using E = V + Ir at any point; short-circuit current is E/r.

level3.content: Using points (I=0.2 A, V=12 V) and (I=1.2 A, V=2 V): gradient = (2−12)/(1.2−0.2) = −10 V A−1, so r = 10 Ω.
E = V + Ir. Using (0.2 A, 12 V): E = 12 + (0.2)(10) = 14 V, so statement I (12 V) is false.
Short-circuit current I_sc = E/r = 14/10 = 1.4 A (not 1.2 A), so only statement II is correct → option B.

common_errors: Assuming the y-intercept is 12 V without checking the line
Using the gradient sign incorrectly (r is the magnitude)
Taking the maximum plotted current as the short-circuit current
